response_parsed.title: _thread Standard Library Module in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This explainer delves into the use of the _thread module in Python 3.12+, a powerful tool for performing parallel and multithreaded programming.
key_points: The _thread module is an extension of the threading library that provides lower-level primitives for managing threads.
It allows more direct access to the underlying platform's threading model, making it faster but less safe than threading.
In Python 3.12+, _thread has been made available in the standard library, providing greater consistency across different platforms.
_thread is suitable for performance-critical applications and tasks that require direct control over threads.
However, using _thread requires a good understanding of concurrency and thread synchronization to avoid data races and other issues.

code_examples.code:
import thread, time

def worker(id):
    print(f'Thread {id} started')
    time.sleep(5)
    print(f'Thread {id} done')

threads = [thread.start_new_thread(worker, (i,)) for i in range(4)]
for thread in threads:
    thread.join()

version_notes: Python 3.12+: The _thread module is now included in the standard library.
Python 3.5 and earlier: The _thread module was part of CPython's source distribution but not part of the standard library.
caveats: _thread has no thread-safe data structures, so you must handle synchronization manually or use third-party libraries like concurrent.futures for more convenient and safer multithreading.
_thread can lead to difficult-to-debug issues when not used carefully, as it allows direct manipulation of platform-specific threading features that may differ across platforms.
